clinical_study.brief_title: Addressing Mental Health Disparities in Refugee Children: A Community-based Participatory Research (CBPR) Collaboration
clinical_study.official_title: Addressing Mental Health Disparities in Refugee Children: A CBPR Collaboration

collaborator.agency: National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities (NIMHD)

brief_summary.textblock: This study will use CBPR mixed methods (qualitative and quantitative data collection) to conduct needs assessments and design and evaluate a core family-based intervention. Project activities will emphasize capacity building in two refugee communities resettled in Greater Boston—the Somali Bantu and the Bhutanese—actively engaging refugee community members, community advisory boards, services providers, and other stakeholders. Specific Aims are to: (1) deepen partnerships with the Somali Bantu and Bhutanese communities through co-leadership, capacity-building, and knowledge sharing; (2) collect and apply qualitative data to (a) prepare a needs assessment of mental health in children and adolescents, barriers to care, and services preferences with each target refugee group; (b) develop mental health/psychosocial assessments for refugee caregivers and children; (c) adapt the core components of a family-based strengthening intervention for use with refugees; and (3) conduct an 80-family pilot study to examine acceptability and sustainability of the intervention. Key outcomes will be reduced mental health symptoms among children and adolescents and improvement in caregiver-child relationships.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in depressive symptoms among children and adolescents
primary_outcome.time_frame: Depressive symptoms will be measured at three time points - at baseline prior to intervention, immediately post-intervention (an average of 16 weeks after baseline), and 6 months after the completion of the intervention
primary_outcome.description: Depressive symptoms will be measured with an adapted version of the Center for Epidemiologic Study-Depression) CES-D scale

primary_outcome.measure: Change in anxiety symptoms among children and adolescents
primary_outcome.time_frame: Anxiety symptoms will be measured at three time points - at baseline prior to intervention, immediately post intervention (an average of 16 weeks after baseline), and six months after the completion of the intervention
primary_outcome.description: Anxiety symptoms will be measured with an adapted version of the CES-D

primary_outcome.measure: Change in externalizing/behavioral problems among children and adolescents
primary_outcome.time_frame: Externalizing symptoms will be measured at three time points - at baseline prior to intervention, immediately post-intervention (an average of 16 weeks after the baseline), and 6 months after the completion of the intervention
primary_outcome.description: Externalizing symptoms will be measured with the (Youth Self-Report) YSR externalizing sub scale

primary_outcome.time_frame: Quality of parent-child relationships will be measured at three time points - at baseline prior to intervention, immediately post-intervention (an average of 16 weeks after the baseline), and 6 months after the completion of the intervention.
primary_outcome.description: Parent-child relationships will be measured with an adapted version of the Alabama parenting scale

arm_group.description: Family Strengthening Intervention-Refugees. A total of 20 Somali Bantu and 20 Bhutanese refugee families will participate in a Family Strengthening Intervention adapted for use with refugees.
A total of 20 Somali Bantu and 20 Bhutanese refugee families will receive services as usual.

intervention.description: This study aims to design a preventive intervention for at-risk refugee children and families. The intervention is focused on strengthening core family resources and promoting resilience and healthy parent-child interactions.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Refugee families must have a school-aged child (aged 5-17), and caregivers must be at least 18 years of age and live in the same household as the child.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Untreated mental illness or active family crisis
